newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israel's Netanyahu blasts UN anti-settlement vote.
newsitem.headline: Israel's Netanyahu blasts UN anti-settlement vote.

text.p: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Wednesday blasted the United Nations over a General Assembly vote that urged member states to actively discourage the building of Jewish settlements in occupied areas.
He dismissed the settlements issue as a "red herring" and called on the Palestinians to negotiate it in peace talks with Israel in place of stirring up world condemnation in the United Nations.
"There's so much happening in the world. There's fighting. There are wars. There is genocide. And this is what the U.N. has to do?" Netanyahu said on the U.S. Cable News Network (CNN).
"To convene a whole General Assembly special session because we are building some housing for young couples, incidentally for Arabs and Jews alike?"

Tuesday's General Assembly resolution, sponsored by 15 Arab and Moslem nations, condemned Israeli settlement activity and, in a move toward sanctions, demanded Israel provide information about goods produced in the settlements.
The vote was 131-3 with 14 abstentions. Israel, Micronesia and the United States voted against.
An aide to Netanyahu, David Bar-Illan, called the decision "shameful" and "morally bankrupt".

The resolution follows a report by U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan condemning Israel for not abandoning settlement construction at a site in Arab East Jerusalem called Har Homa in Hebrew and Jabal Abu Ghneim in Arabic.
The Assembly demanded at an emergency special session in April that Israel halt work at the Jerusalem site, where bulldozers are preparing the infrastructure for 6,500 homes.
The start of construction last March plunged Israel-PLO peacemaking into crisis and triggered waves of Palestinian unrest in the West Bank and Gaza, captured in the 1967 Middle East War.
Israel, which captured East Jerusalem in 1967 and later annexed it in a move the international community has not recognised, says all of Jerusalem is its united capital.

Arabs view the Jerusalem construction and other settlement activity as an attempt to pre-empt future peace talks on the West Bank, wanted by Palestinians as part of a future state with its capital in East Jerusalem.
Netanyahu scoffed at charges that Israel was pre-empting talks.

"The total area of the settlements as a proportion of the built-up areas of the West Bank is about one percent...the whole idea that we're pre-empting the other 99 percent is ridiculous," he said. "It's a non-issue. A red herring."

The new resolution recommends that the parties to the Fourth Geneva Convention, which bars settlements in occupied territory, convene a conference on measures to enforce the convention and asks the secretary-general to provide a report in three months.

The resolution recommends that U.N. members "actively discourage activities which directly contribute to any construction or development of Israeli settlements in occupied Palestinian territory, including Jerusalem."
